awd_titl_txt: Accumulation of particles and organisms in density stratified fluids with applications in algal blooms
awd_abstract_narration:
CBET - 1604423
PI: Ardekani, Arezoo

Many aquatic systems, including oceans, often have regions where the water density varies with depth owing to variations in temperature and salinity. These regions of water density stratification are associated with formation of algal blooms and accumulation of marine snow particles. This project comprises computational and experimental studies to test the hypothesis that density stratification leads to enhanced horizontal clustering of particles and organisms, especially those with elongated shapes. Furthermore, the project will investigate whether density stratification suppresses convection plumes that can disperse algal cells, leading to accumulation of cells. The equations that govern the motion of fluid and particles will be solved numerically and results will be compared with experiments to visualize the motion of algal cells and particles in water with density stratification. Some algal blooms are toxic, and they pose serious problems in coastal waters, including reduced oxygen content, increased marine animal mortality, and increased fouling of marine equipment. This project will help uncover the mechanisms of algal bloom formation, which could lead to new strategies to control it. The project will provide opportunities for students at various academic levels to participate in research, and results of the project will be incorporated in fluid mechanics courses taught by the investigators. 

The lead investigator for this project has recently shown that water density stratification affects not only the dynamics of suspensions of algal cells, but also the motion of individual cells and marine particles. The goal of the proposed research is to quantify effects of density stratification, turbulence and shear, motility and shape of microorganisms on microstructure formation and accumulation of planktonic species by developing a large-scale computational framework to fully resolve the corresponding flows. Three-dimensional Direct Numerical Simulations of the nonlinear equations governing organism and particle transport will be implemented to gain new insights into the mechanisms governing the distribution of planktonic organisms and particles at pycnoclines. Experiments involving particle image velocimetry of algal cells and particles in density stratified liquids with an imposed turbulent flow will be used to obtain parameters needed for the computations and to validate computational results.

por.por_cntn:
Density stratification is an important characteristic of many aquatic environments, e.g., ponds, lakes and oceans. It is caused due to vertical gradients in salt concentration or fluid temperature, which then cause heterogeneity in the fluid density. The biological and/or physical processes associated with swimming microorganisms in a stratified fluid show marked variations than their prototypical behaviors in homogeneous fluids. For example, the flow signature of swimming organisms in a homogeneous fluid is different than that in a stratified fluid, which can have vital implications in predator-prey interactions. Another crucial stratification-induced difference could be a change in the swimming speed of organisms and concomitant energetic expenditure. Dr. Ardekani?s laboratory has used analytical methods to investigate many aspects of organism swimming in stratified fluids. The results of the studies conducted under the auspices of this grant demonstrate interesting stratification-induced changes in microbial swimming, like enhanced swimming speed of undulatory swimmers, non-trivial variation of fluid mixing (caused by swimming organisms) as a function of the diffusivity of the stratifying agent, and the swimming speed depending on the propulsion mechanism of the microorganism. The results of these studies have been published in the Journal of Fluid Mechanics, Physical Review Fluids, Physical Review E, and Soft Matter.

We found that a large density stratification in the fluid mostly hampers the vertical motion of the microorganisms. This results in a swimming velocity which is less than that in a homogeneous fluid. However, when both stratification strength and the diffusivity of the stratifying agent are low, the swimming speed is enhanced, and stratification supports the propulsion of the swimmer. For larger organisms like krill and other large copepods, we found that their swimming velocity is highly sensitive to the stratification strength and diffusion of the stratifying agent in the fluid. We found that for higher stratification strengths, the motion of the swimmer is highly restricted, to an extent that it essentially remains stationary. This analytically calculated result is consistent with the experimentally observed phenomenon of preferential aggregation of swimmers at pycnoclines -regions of sharp changes in water density.

 

We also studied how the propulsion mechanism of marine microorganisms can affect their swimming speed in a stratified fluid. Towards this, we investigated the difference in the swimming behavior of organisms that generate a propulsive thrust in front of their bodies (called ?pullers?, e.g., the alga H. akashiwo) versus those that generate a propulsive thrust at the rear end of their bodies (called ?pushers?, e.g., the dinoflagellate A. carterae). Herein, we showed that far from their neutrally buoyant positions, stratification reduces the speed of both pullers and pushers; whereas is close to their neutrally buoyant positions, stratification increases (resp. decreases) the speed of a puller (resp. pusher).

 In addition to the above original research articles, the PI was also invited to contribute an article to Physical Review Fluids; detailing the ?transport of particles, drops, and small organisms in density stratified fluids?, where we explored the effects of stratification on the fundamental hydrodynamics of settling particles, rising drops, and small organisms. The results of our direct numerical simulations of the sedimentation of particles showed that the presence of vertical density gradients in the water column can substantially affect the settling dynamics of a particle, interaction between a pair of particles, and settling rates and microstructure of suspension of particles. We also showed how stratification can have a major effect on the flow field, energy expenditure, and nutrient uptake of small organisms.

Finally, we investigated the motion of microorganisms near stationary nutrient sources like oil drops and marine snow particles. Quite often, these nutrient sources get trapped in pycnoclines and act as hot-spots for the accumulation of marine bacteria. We used mathematical models and semi-analytical methods to show how hydrodynamic interactions cause microorganisms encountering an oil drop to get ?trapped? onto its surface. Interestingly, this hydrodynamic trapping is stronger if the drop is covered with a surfactant than in the case when it is ?clean?. We also performed experiments to demonstrate this enhanced accumulation of microorganisms near a surfactant-laden interface, as compared to their accumulation near rigid walls.

 

 

 

This project has had a strong educational and outreach component. PI has organized tours of engineering laboratories and outreach sessions for middle and high school female students. The members of the PI Lab have incorporated activities related to concepts like stratification of the water column, in the outreach sessions. Ph.D. students, master students,  undergraduate students, and postdoctoral researchers have been trained as part of this grant. Aspects of this research has been included in a graduate course: ?Complex fluids?, offered at Purdue University. The PI has organized several mini-symposia on active fluids and hydrodynamics of swimming organisms within meetings of SES and IUTAM. The PI and her students have presented several talks in different conferences and workshops, including SES, IUTAM and APS DFD.
